work.title: Hassan
Incidental music to the play by James Elroy Flecker

bibl.author: Dawn Redwood
bibl.title: Flecker and Delius: the making of 'Hassan'

annot.p: Hassan has a complex history and selection of sources. Delius first composed the music to James Elroy Flecker's 5-act drama Hassan in 1920-1, and commissioned Philip Heseltine to prepare a piano score, published by Universal in 1923 (LC II, 243). This version of the music was used in a performance of the play at Darmstadt on 1 June 1923. At the same time, Delius had first been contacted by Basil Dean in January 1921 regarding a London production of the play with Delius's music (LC II, 241). Dean required a number of additions to the score, and Delius also changed the orchestration. A 'new and complete' piano score was subsequently prepared by Heseltine and published by Universal, and Dean's production, with the new music, was first performed on 20 September 1923. To complicate matters, this history occurred as Delius began to experience paralysis, and there are consequently multiple manuscript sources in various hands. Here, the original and expanded versions are treated separately, with the components and orchestration of each provided. Incipits are given for the expanded version only and come from the collected edition. For the 'Intermezzo' and 'Serenade' arrangements by Fenby and Beecham, see the Appendix.
A notebook containing pencil sketch material for Hassan.

titleStmt.title: Original pencil score and other items

notesStmt.annot: This source contains the following (i) the majority of Delius's original autograph pencil score (ii) manuscripts of most of the additional sections composed for the London performance, in Jelka's hand (iii) a manuscript of the 'Serenade', arranged for solo cello and chamber orchestra by Eric Fenby and (iv) a copy of the full score in its final form by Eric Fenby, missing some items (RT, 149).

annot.p: A fragment of the music for Act I, Scene 2, from the dispersed original pencil score.

titlePage.p:
HASSAN
or The Golden Journey to Samarkand
Incidental music to James Elroy Flecker's play, by Frederick Delius
Full score

annot.p: This manuscript contains the 'Prelude to Act I', 'Divertissement' and 'Act IV Prelude' from Delius's original pencil score, inked over (possibly by Heseltine). The rest of the manuscript is a transcription of the rest of Delius's score in black ink by Heseltine. The instrumentation, stage directions and tempo indications have been added in German by Jelka Delius throughout. This item was used by Universal Edition to raise the orchestral material for the Darmstadt performance.
This manuscript contains a number of sketches for the revised version of Hassan, with parts in Jelka's hands and marginal notes by Fenby.

This sketch material, using reduced scoring, corresponds to part of the 'General Dance' in the Act II ballet, from p. 86 onwards in the collected edition. The sketch is headed 'Sketches for "Dance" for "Hassan"/late July, 1923, Lesjaskog'.

Full score in the hands of two professional copyists, consisting of an initial copy based upon MS Mus. 1745/3/7/1, supplemented by additional pages in the hand of the second copyist prepared for the London production. The additional pages derive from material in Jelka Delius's hand now in MS Mus. 1745/2/4.

This score consists of the original version of the music in black ink in a copyist's hand, supplemented by the additional material in the hands of four additional copyists. The manuscript also contains some of Beecham's markings. It was used for the London performance, and formerly owned by Basil Dean.
